title: 103_hr4897
content: The "Child Support Enforcement Act of 1994" allows for the seizure of lottery winnings, settlements, payouts, and sale of forfeited property to pay child support arrearages. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for imposing a lien on winnings from state lotteries or gambling establishments to withhold payment until a child support arrearage is determined by the state agency. The State child support enforcement agency can withhold payment from a person if they owe child support arrearage. Payments from insurance policies or settlements can also be suspended until the agency confirms if the person owes child support. The policy allows for the suspension of payments if there is a child support arrearage, with the withheld amount being paid to the State agency for distribution. Payments from insurance policies or settlements can also be suspended until the agency confirms the child support owed. The payor must suspend payments if there is a child support arrearage and withhold the amount owed for distribution to the State agency. Payments from legal actions must also be suspended until the agency confirms any arrearage. If a State seizes property forfeited by an individual due to a criminal conviction, they must hold the property until confirming with the State agency if the individual owes child support arrears. The State agency can withhold and distribute the amount owed from the payment. If a State seizes property forfeited by an individual due to a criminal conviction, they must hold the property until confirming with the State agency if the individual owes child support arrears. The State shall sell the property if there is an arrearage, satisfy claims of other claimants, deduct costs, and pay the remaining proceeds to the individual. When a State seizes forfeited property, they must confirm if the individual owes child support arrears before selling the property. The State will then satisfy claims of other claimants, deduct costs, and pay the remaining proceeds to the individual. If a person is required to make a payment in respect to a decedent, they must suspend the payment until confirming with the State agency about any child support arrearages. When a payment is due in relation to a deceased individual, it must be suspended until confirmation is received from the State agency regarding any child support arrears. If arrears exist, the payment will be withheld and the amount paid to the State agency for distribution. SEC. 3. RESTRICTIONS RELATING TO PROFESSIONAL, OCCUPATIONAL, BUSINESS, AND DRIVER'S LICENSES. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for State licensing departments to withhold licenses from noncustodial parents with outstanding child support warrants and individuals delinquent in child support payments. The State's crime information system may hold a license for individuals delinquent in child support payments until consent is given by a prosecutor or court, or an expedited review is completed. The State motor vehicle department is prohibited from issuing or renewing licenses or vehicle registrations for noncustodial parents with outstanding child support warrants. The State motor vehicle department is prohibited from issuing or renewing driver's licenses or vehicle registrations for noncustodial parents with outstanding child support warrants. Upon receiving notice of a warrant related to child support, the department must order the individual to show cause for retaining their license or registration. The State motor vehicle department must order individuals with child support warrants to show cause for retaining their driver's license or vehicle registration. Temporary licenses may be granted pending compliance with the order or removal of the warrant. SEC. 4. ATTACHMENT OF BANK ACCOUNTS. Section 466(a) (42 U.S.C. 666(a)) is amended to allow seizure of funds in a bank account to pay child support arrears through an administrative process, with notice and opportunity to be heard for the account holder. The amendment allows seizure of funds in a bank account to pay child support arrears through an administrative process, with notice and opportunity to be heard for the account holder. SEC. 5 amends the Social Security Act to require courts to report child support obligations to credit bureaus. SEC. 6 addresses the liability of grandparents for financial support of their grandchildren. SEC. 6 amends the Social Security Act to make each parent liable for the financial support of their child if the individual is unable to provide such support.
